content.webTitle: Germaine Greer tells Q&A Shakespeare's timeless lesson is to make us think

fields.headline: Germaine Greer tells Q&A Shakespeare's timeless lesson is to make us think
fields.bodyText: Shakespeare still has a lot to teach because he never offers easy answers, Germaine Greer has told the Q&A audience in a special edition of the program focusing on the playwright. “What actually happens in a Shakespeare play is you’re prevented from arriving at easy certainties,” Greer said. “Everything you think you understand is challenged. So you have to recast your ideas. “This is what makes the plays work – because everything keeps shifting.” The philosopher AC Grayling agreed, saying: “Shakespeare’s a wonderful resource ... in getting us to see things about despair, ambition, desire, the passion for vengeance, love, all these things.” The panel explored gender, race and class in Shakespeare and the bearing his plays have on contemporary politics. Greer also used the episode to pay tribute to Richard Neville, the writer and co-founder of the controversial counterculture magazine Oz, who died on Sunday night. Greer said: “I’m sad today because Richard is gone but in fact we lost him some time ago when he became ill. Another part of me is glad that it’s over. That the struggle is over and he is at peace. “He was unafraid, he was supple-minded, he was open to new ideas, he was adventurous. “He was also charming. And we haven’t got that many charming men.” The founding artistic director of Bell Shakespeare, John Bell, said Shakespeare could be adapted to illuminate contemporary politics. “I’d be interested to see a production of The Merchant of Venice where you substituted the word Muslim for Jew and see how that would resonate,” Bell said. Greer, Bell and Grayling were joined by Indigenous actor Kylie Farmer and the actor and playwright Kate Mulvany to canvass Shakespeare’s work, in a markedly different Q&A, free of political talking points. Asked whether Shakespeare’s plays should be used to subsidise new Australian work, Greer said: “It is obviously possible, and yes, I would. But what worries me slightly is the assumption that Shakespeare’s kind of olde worlde and not of today, and so forth. The reason that we speak Shakespearean is because it is still current for us.” Bell said that he done precisely that when he was running the Nimrod threatre. Neither Bell nor Greer agreed there should be a moratorium on Shakespeare to make room for new playwrights. “Anything in culture needs a balance of classics and new work. It’s just a matter of working out the proportions. Audience need to see the classics,” Bell said. The panellists talked about Shakespeare’s bearing on their own lives. Mulvany said: “He teaches me as a human because of the way he crystallises and encapsulates a moment in a word or a phrase. What he teaches me as a playwright is extraordinary though too.” The episode concluded with Bell reading a speech on refugees “from a play called Sir Thomas More, which Shakespeare wrote in collaboration with a younger writer” that referred to a nation’s “mountainish inhumanity”. “In this speech Sir Thomas More is confronting the protesters and the mobs who want all the refugees removed from London,” Bell said. He recited from the play, asking the Q&A audience to: “Imagine that you see the wretched strangers, Their babies at their backs and their poor luggage, Plodding to the ports and coasts for transportation.”
